tips.tip: Bronchoscopy can detect MAC when multiple sputum samples are negative, especially when CT scans show progression. Linda Esposito had three negative sputum samples over time, but after CT showed progression at 3 months, bronchoscopy verified MAC. Multiple patients report always having negative sputums but bronchoscopies consistently show MAC is still present. However, try hypertonic saline-induced sputum first - it's non-invasive and may eliminate the need for bronchoscopy. Sputum samples can miss MAC because mycobacteria live deep in alveoli and aren't always present in expectorated mucus. This is especially true for patients with bronchiectasis who may not bring up representative samples. Bronchoscopy with bronchial lavage directly samples deeper lung tissue, increasing detection sensitivity. However, hypertonic saline nebulization can induce more productive coughing and should be attempted before invasive procedures. If you've had 2-3 negative sputum cultures but CT scan shows new cavities, nodules, or disease progression, ask your pulmonologist about hypertonic saline-induced sputum collection first. If sputums remain negative despite clear radiological progression, bronchoscopy may be necessary for definitive diagnosis. CINDY GILBERT always has negative sputums but bronchoscopies consistently show MAC presence, demonstrating the diagnostic gap.

Bronchoscopy carries infection risk - multiple patients developed MAC or immediate infections after the procedure. One anonymous patient had stable bronchiectasis for 2 years, underwent bronchoscopy (with 'huge quantity' of mucus sampled), all specimens were negative, then tested positive for MAC one month later. Linda Gatlin developed immediate infection from bronchoscopy and 6 months later sputum showed M. avium. Jenny Smith's lung collapsed post-procedure requiring emergency chest tube placement, then developed severe MAC 2 months later. Bronchoscopy introduces external instruments into the airway, potentially carrying NTM from water sources, inadequate sterilization, or contaminated equipment. The lavage solution itself could theoretically introduce organisms. Risk is particularly concerning for patients with bronchiectasis who don't yet have confirmed NTM - the procedure meant to diagnose may actually cause infection. Pneumothorax (collapsed lung) is a known complication requiring signing consent forms that protect providers. Before agreeing to bronchoscopy, weigh the diagnostic benefit against infection risk. If you have bronchiectasis without confirmed NTM and negative sputums, try exhausting non-invasive options first: hypertonic saline-induced sputum (if pulmonologist didn't suggest this, ask why not), multiple sputum samples over time, and correlation with CT findings. If bronchoscopy is necessary, ask about their sterilization protocols for bronchoscopes and what water source is used for lavage solution. Monitor closely for new symptoms post-procedure - one patient 'could barely walk from one room to the other' 2 months after bronchoscopy due to severe MAC.

For mucus plug removal, bronchial lavage during bronchoscopy is invasive with infection risk - pursue aggressive non-invasive airway clearance first. Sue Sherek shared research showing preferred non-drug treatments for mucus plugs (especially without active infection): manual techniques, pulmonary physical/respiratory therapy with percussive techniques, and regular airway clearance. Mamie Balestra successfully used pulmonary PT with percussion to bring up mucus and plugs non-invasively. Mucus plugging on CT scans is common with bronchiectasis (Catherine Cabbell: 'that's what happens when we have bronch as our cilia don't clear the mucus as well'). CT reports may describe 'areas of mucus plugging' but this doesn't automatically mean bronchoscopy is needed. Even people without bronchiectasis can have mucus plugs on CT. Bronchial lavage introduces infection risk, especially problematic if you're currently negative for NTM - you could develop infection from the procedure itself. If your pulmonologist suggests bronchoscopy for mucus plug removal and you're currently negative for NTM: (1) Ask about trying intensive airway clearance first - twice daily nebulized saline, manual techniques (autogenic drainage, huff cough), Aerobika or Acapella, (2) Request referral to pulmonary physical therapist for percussive techniques, (3) Consider guaifenesin expectorant (Mucinex) with doctor approval to thin mucus, (4) Use sinus rinse to reduce post-nasal drip contributing to plugs. One anonymous patient does daily airway clearance but still has mucus plugs on CT - doctor isn't concerned, just continues ACT to keep plugs loose and expelled. Only consider bronchoscopy if you have symptoms (can't breathe, recurrent infections) despite maximized ACT, not just because CT mentions plugs.

key_insights: These threads reveal bronchoscopy's dual nature: valuable diagnostic tool vs potential infection vector - Bronchoscopy solves the 'hidden MAC' problem (negative sputums with radiological progression) but multiple patients attribute their MAC infections to the procedure itself. This creates a diagnostic dilemma: the test meant to detect infection may cause it. The medical community hasn't fully addressed this paradox - pulmonologists readily order bronchoscopies without acknowledging contamination risk, and patients only learn about infection complications through peer sharing, not provider warnings. Resolution requires: (1) exhausting non-invasive options first (hypertonic saline-induced sputum), (2) strict bronchoscope sterilization protocols, (3) informed consent that includes NTM infection risk (not just standard pneumothorax risk), (4) post-procedure monitoring for new MAC symptoms.

Hypertonic saline-induced sputum is dramatically underutilized as bronchoscopy alternative - Multiple patients report pulmonologists jumped straight to bronchoscopy without ever suggesting hypertonic saline to induce more productive cough. One anonymous patient: pulmonologist 'never suggested hypertonic saline to induce sputum' before insisting on bronchoscopy, which found 'huge quantity' of mucus but was negative - then one month later patient was MAC-positive (drawing clear implication bronchoscopy caused infection). Sue Sherek's research link showing non-invasive mucus management as preferred first-line wasn't part of standard medical conversation. This represents system failure: providers aren't following evidence-based stepwise approach (non-invasive → minimally invasive → invasive). Patients must advocate for trying HS-induced sputum before consenting to bronchoscopy.

Bronchoscopy timing matters - 'stable disease' vs 'progression' determines appropriateness - Appropriate use: CT shows new cavity, enlarging nodules, or progression despite negative sputums → bronchoscopy justified for definitive diagnosis before starting treatment. Inappropriate use: mucus plugs on CT without symptoms in NTM-negative patient → high risk, low benefit (ACT is first-line). The threads show confusion: Kathy Chigbrow's pulmonologist suggested bronchoscopy to remove mucus plugs despite being NTM-negative (peers warned against this), while Tamara Horne's new cavity despite three negative sputums clearly warranted bronchoscopy. Patients need framework: bronchoscopy for diagnostic confirmation when clinical suspicion high (symptoms + CT progression), not for therapeutic mucus removal in low-risk patients.

The 'always negative sputums but bronchoscopy shows MAC' pattern reveals sputum sampling limitations - CINDY GILBERT's experience ('I always have negative sputums, but the bronchs always show the MAC is still there') exposes fundamental limitation of sputum monitoring for treatment response. If you're one of these patients, you can never trust sputum negativity - CT scans and symptoms become more important than culture results. This has major implications: (1) can't use sputum conversion as treatment endpoint (must rely on 12+ month radiological stability), (2) 'negative cultures' don't mean you can stop treatment early, (3) may need periodic bronchoscopies to verify true treatment success (though infection risk remains concern). Providers need to identify these 'non-expectorators' early and adjust monitoring strategy accordingly.

common_questions.question: When should I agree to bronchoscopy versus trying sputum samples first?
common_questions.answer: Bronchoscopy is appropriate when: (1) You have 2-3 negative sputum cultures BUT CT shows new cavities, enlarging nodules, or clear disease progression, (2) You have strong symptoms (severe cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, night sweats) with negative sputums but suspicious imaging, (3) Your doctor needs to rule out cancer vs infection when nodules are growing rapidly. Bronchoscopy is premature when: (1) You haven't tried hypertonic saline-induced sputum collection (ask specifically if your pulmonologist didn't mention this), (2) You only have mucus plugs on CT without symptoms and are currently NTM-negative, (3) CT is stable and you feel well despite negative sputums. Linda Esposito's case shows appropriate use: three negative sputums, CT progression at 3 months, bronchoscopy verified MAC and treatment started. Anonymous patient's case shows inappropriate use: stable bronchiectasis 2 years, bronch ordered 'to rule out MAC' without trying hypertonic saline first, all specimens negative, then MAC-positive one month later suggesting procedure caused infection.

common_questions.question: What's the real risk of getting MAC from the bronchoscopy procedure itself?
common_questions.answer: Multiple patients report strong temporal connection between bronchoscopy and MAC diagnosis: Linda Gatlin got immediate infection from bronchoscopy plus M. avium 6 months later ("I can't prove it was from the bronchoscopy but I am sure that's what happened"), anonymous patient had all negative bronch specimens then MAC-positive one month later, Jenny Smith's lung collapsed post-procedure then severe MAC 2 months later. The mechanism: inadequately sterilized bronchoscopes, contaminated lavage water, or introducing organisms from upper airways into lower lungs. Medical consent forms warn about pneumothorax (collapsed lung) but not infection risk - Jenny Smith notes 'you sign off on that so it's all protected on their end.' To reduce risk: ask about bronchoscope sterilization protocols (high-level disinfection after each use), what water source is used for lavage, and request procedure be done at high-volume center (National Jewish Hospital, UT Tyler, Cleveland Clinic) where protocols are likely more rigorous. One patient states 'I won't be getting bronch'd again' after negative results then MAC diagnosis.

common_questions.question: Should I get bronchoscopy to remove mucus plugs if my CT shows this?
common_questions.answer: Probably not, especially if you're currently NTM-negative. Mucus plugging on CT is very common with bronchiectasis and doesn't automatically require bronchoscopy. Catherine Cabbell explains: 'They are what happens when we have bronch as our cilia don't clear the mucus as well and it builds up. That's why we do airway clearance.' She always has mucus plugs on CT scans, her pulmonologist isn't worried, just continues airway clearance to keep them loose and expelled. Even her friend WITHOUT bronchiectasis or lung problems had mucus plugs on CT. Sue Sherek shared research showing preferred non-drug treatments: manual airway clearance techniques, not invasive procedures. First-line approach: (1) Maximize airway clearance - twice daily nebulized saline, manual techniques, Aerobika, (2) Try guaifenesin (Mucinex) with doctor approval, (3) Request pulmonary physical therapy referral for percussive techniques (Mamie Balestra: 'good amount of success' with this), (4) Use sinus rinse to reduce post-nasal drip. Only consider bronchoscopy if you can't breathe despite these measures AND you already have confirmed NTM (infection risk less concerning if you're already infected). Risk-benefit heavily favors non-invasive approach for asymptomatic mucus plugs.

common_questions.question: If I always have negative sputum cultures but bronchoscopy shows MAC, how do I monitor treatment?
common_questions.answer: You're a 'non-expectorator' and sputum monitoring is unreliable for you. CINDY GILBERT's pattern: 'I always have negative sputums, but the bronchs always show the MAC is still there.' For treatment monitoring: (1) Rely primarily on CT scans every 4-6 months to track nodules, cavities, tree-in-bud changes - radiological improvement is your main endpoint, (2) Track symptoms (cough frequency, mucus production, energy level, weight) consistently - symptom improvement despite negative sputums suggests treatment working, (3) Don't use sputum conversion as reason to stop treatment early - you may need full 12 months after radiological stability rather than 12 months after first negative culture, (4) Consider periodic bronchoscopies (every 6-12 months during treatment, then post-treatment) to verify true clearance, though weigh infection risk, (5) Discuss with provider whether to extend treatment duration since you can't rely on culture conversion. Never assume 'negative sputum = cured' if you're in this category. CT stability over 12+ months is more meaningful than negative cultures.
